title: Inequality
subtitle: How skewed is the CIE towards a small set of accounts?
text:
We evaluate inequality using the Gini coefficient 
           (the extent influence within an information ecosystem deviates from a perfectly even distribution). 
           The scale ranges from 0 (each entity has equal influence) to 1 (a single entity has all the influence). 
           Fewer information sources (high value) severely restrict information flows, which can lead to faster spread 
           and deeper penetration of misinformation.

title: Segmentation
subtitle: How divided is the CIE into distinct communities?
text:
We evaluate polarization through segmentation (the extent a network is divided into distinct communities, 
           0=low segmentation and 1=high segmentation).

title: Insularity
subtitle: How insular are major political parties relative to one another?
text:
We evaluate insularity (the extent political party families engage with others outside their political party, with a higher number 
            representing a more insular party family).

title: Toxic speech
subtitle: How prevalent is toxic speech in the CIE?
text: We evaluate toxicity through toxic speech (presence of toxic speech among posts by political influencers, with lower values indicating lower toxicity).

title: News avoidance
subtitle: To what extent do people avoid political and public affairs news?
text: We evaluate news avoidance (extent people avoid the news all together, 0=low to 1=high).

title: Trust in information gatekeepers
subtitle: How much do people trust information gatekeepers?
text: We evaluate trust by asking Canadians about their confidence in information gatekeepers (journalists, media organizations, politicians, and big tech).

title: Chilled speech
subtitle: To what extent do people avoid political discussion and opinion sharing?
text: We evaluate chilled speech (extent people avoid online political discussion and opinion sharing, 0=low to 1=high).

title: Concern about misinformation
subtitle: How concerned are people about misinformation?
text: We evaluate the threat of misinformation by measuring Canadians’ concern about misinformation.

title: Concern about foreign influence
subtitle: How concerned are people about foreign influence?
text: We evaluate the threat of foreign influence by measuring concern about foreign governments influencing Canadian media and politics (in general and by country).

title: Concern about Generative AI
subtitle: How concerned are people about artificial intelligence?
text: We assess the threat of generative AI by measuring concern about AI generated content misleading the general public.

title: Directed foreign influence
subtitle: To what extent are overt foreign influencers impacting CIE?
text: We assess how ‘close’ foreign accounts are to Canadian accounts in regards to the content they share: we can understand these accounts to be in close proximity to the CIE if they frequently post similar links or discuss certain topics at the same time and in the same way.

title: Links to known misinformation websites
subtitle: How common and popular are web links to known misinformation websites?
text: We measure how much misinformation is circulated in the CIE by politically influential accounts. We do not measure how much misinformation in total there is in the CIE – that would require us to analyze every single post across multiple platforms in Canada.

title: Discussion about misinformation and foreign interference
subtitle: How often do people post about misinformation and foreign influence?
text: We analyze discussion about misinformation to assess the level of attention it is getting. Examining how often prominent accounts within the CIE provides an additional dimension to our analysis of concern about misinformation.

title: News seeking
subtitle: How many people seek out information about news?
text: We report the proportion of respondents who say “Occasionally seeking out”, “Often seeking out”, and “Constantly seeking out”.

title: News sharing
subtitle: How actively people share and post news on social media?
text: We calculate the proportion who say “Once or twice a week” or more and then average the proportions to generate an overall news sharing measure.

title: Mediums of weekly news
subtitle: How many people use each medium weekly for news?
text: We calculate the proportion who say “once or twice a week” or more to generate a news consumption score for each news medium.

title: Top 5 news outlets
subtitle: What are the top 5 Canadian news outlets? What is their share of total engagement?
text: We first identify the five outlets that received the highest amount of engagement (as measured by the total number of likes, comments, and shares on their posts), sum them, then divide their engagement by the total amount of engagement received by Canadian news outlets online and multiplying by 100. We are then able to see how much of online Canadian news engagement is generated by the biggest outlets.

title: Local vs National news engagement
subtitle: How skewed is preference for national vs local news?
text: We calculate the relative local news engagement by dividing the total amount of engagement generated by local news accounts across our platforms by the total amount of engagement generated by all news accounts.

title: Platforms used by news outlets
subtitle: Which social media platforms are most popular for news?
text: We evaluate on which platforms Canadian news outlets receive the most engagement to better understand where Canadians seek their online news content. We calculate the platform with the most engagement with Canadian news outlets by summing the total number of likes on posts by Canadian news outlets per platform, and reporting the platform with the most likes.

title: Top social media platforms
subtitle: Which social media platforms are most popular for Canadian politicians?
text: We identify the most popular platform for engagement with politicians by adding up the total number of likes on posts by Canadian politicians across our platforms for the whole month, then identifying which platform generated the most likes.

title: Engagement with party leaders
subtitle: Which federal party leaders are most engaging with Canadians?
text: We compare the engagement rates of the leaders of Canadian federal political parties which currently hold seats in the House of Commons. This is calculated by summing the total amount of likes each leader receives on their posts across our platforms of interest, then representing these likes as a percentage of all likes received by all party leaders.

title: Engagement with elected party members
subtitle: Which elected party members are most engaging with Canadians?
text: We compare the engagement rates of all Canadian party ‘families’ (Liberal, NDP, Conservative, Bloc Quebecois, Green). We sum the total amount of engagement received by each party’s politicians, on both the federal and provincial level, then dividing that sum by the total amount of engagement received by Canadian politicians who are not party leaders.

title: Engagement with Politicians vs News
subtitle: How skewed is engagement with politicians vs news outlets?
text: We report the percentage of engagement generated by Canadian politicians relative to Canadian news outlets to gain an idea of how prominent politicians are in the CIE. We calculate this percentage by dividing the total number of likes received by Canadian politicians by the total number of likes received by both news outlets and politicians.
